text: So I've been making some rather large updates to my personal portfolio of work, including some content changes. I'm curious about the best ways to present or display digital work - most of my work is with games, but I have a few apps on there too. I'm looking to the Uncorked and other agency portfolios, but I'd love to get some more references, especially for interactive work.
<@U02AVBGQC> Take a look at Instrument, Teehan Lax, Huge

text: as mediums shift and interactive work becomes much more about the actual interactivity, still screens become less and less relevant. There is an increasing emphasis on good ol' fashioned words to communicate project goals and context for interactive projects.
Very interesting. This is really helpful. Thanks, <@U0260V1BX>!
np!
The only thing I would add is avoid awkward scrolls like the ones on <http://www.hugeinc.com/>
It's not good for the user.
Haha, I use Wordpress, so I'm pretty limited in how crazy I can get in my theme.
Hah, I just had the Huge homepage open for a couple minutes and now my lap is on _fire_ from my machine running too hard.
It's funny how Huge is getting so much praise for good "mobile UX" but their site is probably not good for you phone's battery which is an important consideration for mobile devices.
Goes back to the "Kill the UX Designer" post from the other day. Web design isn't just about visuals but how it works in the context where the user is viewing the site. </rant>
In defense of Huge - i think context is important to understanding the praise they get
Is their mobile site the most efficient? No. But is does it convey a vision and a skillest to the people to might want to hire them? Yes.
I wouldn't want to have to use that site for much more than a couple minutes, but I'm also NOT going to be using it for more than a couple minutes
all that said - I think their overall skill set has degraded pretty heavily in the last couple years
and they're for more flashy than functional

I partially agree with that. Because as "creators of web things" their responsibility goes beyond communicating information. They are responsible for making their experiences accessible and functional. They're free to do whatever they want to do but they're still responsible for the good and bad aspects of their experience.
sure - but "good" and "bad" in this context are, I think, subjective
and again - Im not necessarily arguing in support of this particular design - more than there is a calculus to design that resists strongly any set notion of "good" and "bad"
Agreed. Good/bad was a poor choice of word.
I guess the problem is that they seem to prefer form over function and our industry seems to be encouraging that. Which in turns encourages new designers to do the same.

well - like I said, I think nearly of their best minds left a couple years ago - so I'm not surprised their work has gone down hill. Also, since they were bought by IPG what they're being asked to be is a little different - which is a profit center
to that end, it's a lot easier to sell work that looks obviously amazing in the first 30 seconds
but again - on the spectrum of whomever we consider "the best" to whomever we consider "the worst" I'd still put them much further up the list than down it
and I also think we're in the middle of third wave of interactive design
and people are still trying to sort it out
if you want to see form over function - go back to the early 2000's
which lead to a period of deep consideration of pure function
which - I think - has lead us back to a place where people want heart
<http://youtu.be/xwZqQnSd3Oo>
